topics.name: The Occupational Safety and Health (OSH) Act

par.span: On December 29, 1970, President Nixon signed the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 (OSH Act) into law, establishing the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA).
It is a national public health agency which is dedicated to protecting America’s workers so that no worker should have to choose between their life and job.
The purpose of the OSH Act is: “to assure so far as possible every working man and woman in the Nation safe and healthful working conditions and to preserve our human resources."

topics.name: Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER)

par.span: The dumping of hazardous substances poses a significant threat and is a serious safety and health problem that continues to endanger the lives of humans and animals and the quality of their environment.
The seriousness of this issue has led to OSHA issuing the HAZWOPER Standard.
HAZWOPER stands for Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response. HAZWOPER regulations are covered under the Title
This standard was issued to protect the health and safety of those working at waste sites and to help them handle hazardous substances safely and effectively.
OSHA requires HAZWOPER training for anyone who is:

li.span: Cleaning up hazardous waste sites;
Working with hazardous waste at treatment, storage, and disposal sites; or
Responding to emergencies concerning hazardous material releases.

par.span: The HAZWOPER regulation
contains 17 different sections. There are also five appendices, Appendix A to Appendix E, that help employers and employees comply with the regulations of this standard.
Under federal code, Title 29 CFR 1910.120 establishes Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response regulations concerning:

Sections (b) to (o) of the standard regulates operations where employees are engaged in the cleanup of uncontrolled hazardous waste sites.
Section (e) of the HAZWOPER regulation applies to general site workers, and this is by far the largest number of people requiring the HAZWOPER training.
Certain Operations Conducted Under RCRA
Section (p) covers those employees who are engaged in treatment, storage and disposal (TSD) facility operations for hazardous waste.
Emergency Response to Hazardous Substance Releases
Section (q) covers emergency responders for releases of hazardous substances without regard to the location of the hazard.

par.span: There are five appendices to the HAZWOPER regulation that assist employers and employees in complying with the provisions of this standard. These include:

span.a: Appendix A: Personal protective clothing test methods
Appendix B: General description and discussion of the levels of protection and protective gear

par.span: HAZWOPER regulations apply in the following work areas:

li.span: Clean-up operations required by a government body, whether local, state, federal or other, involving hazardous substances at uncontrolled hazardous waste sites.
Corrective measures and clean- up activities at sites covered by the 1976 Resource Conservation and Recovery Act( RCRA).
Voluntary clean-up operations at uncontrolled hazardous waste sites by local, state and federal government bodies.
Operations involving hazardous waste carried out in treatment, storage or disposal facilities (TSD), by agencies in accordance with the EPA Regulation.
Emergency response operations for the release of, or substantial threats of the release of, hazardous substances without regard to the location of the hazard.

par.span: There are several types of HAZWOPER training for the general site worker depending on your job type and experience:

li.span: 40-hour training
24-hour training
8-hour annual refresher

par.span: The 40-hour course, which you are just beginning, is intended for workers who perform activities that could expose or potentially expose them
to hazardous substances above the Permissible Exposure Limit (PEL) established by OSHA. These individuals usually require the use of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE).
The 24-hour HAZWOPER course is for workers who have a temporary or short-term assignment at a HAZWOPER site and will not be exposed to hazardous materials above the PEL established by OSHA,
and therefore will not require respiratory protection. These individuals do not require the use of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE).
The 8-hour annual refresher course is required for both the 24-hour and 40-hour certified individuals to re-emphasize the initial training and to update workers on any new policies or procedures.
The level of training provided to general site workers should be consistent with their job function and responsibilities.
General site workers represent the largest group of people who require the HAZWOPER training. According to OSHA, training should include instruction in the following areas:

li.span: Site Safety and Health plan;
Safe work practices;
Expected nature of hazards at the worksite;
Sampling and monitoring procedures;
Safe and effective use of personal protective equipment (PPE);
Employee rights and responsibilities; and
Site emergencies, rescue and evacuation procedures.

topics.name: The HAZWOPER Standard and Other Regulations

par.span: A number of work tasks performed at a HAZWOPER work-site may over lap and cross over into other areas regulated by OSHA.
All of these areas are related to HAZWOPER and will be discussed in detail in the modules that follow.
For example Bloodborne Pathogens Standard (29 CFR 1020.1030), Respiratory Protection Standard (29 CFR 1020.134) etc.

par.span: Under the OSH Act, employers have the following responsibilities:

li.span: Conspicuously display the OSHA’s Job Safety and Health poster.
Inform workers about chemical hazards through training, labels, alarms, color-coded systems, chemical information sheets and various other methods.
Maintain records of work-related injuries and illnesses with accuracy.
Perform tests in the workplace that are required by OSHA standards, such as air sampling.
Provide required personal protective equipment (PPE) at no cost to employee.
Provide medical tests required by OSHA standards.
Notify OSHA within 8 hours of a workplace fatality.
Not retaliate against workers for using their rights as given to them under this law; including their right to report a work-related complaint.

par.span: Under the OSH Act employees have the following rights:

li.span: File a confidential complaint with OSHA for workplace inspection.
Receive information and training related to hazards, methods to prevent harm, and OSHA standards that apply to their workplace.
Be given training that must be done in a language that is easy for the workers to understand.
Receive information about work-related injuries and illnesses that occur in their workplace.
Receive the results obtained from tests and monitoring done to find and measure hazards in their workplace.
Receive copies of their work-related medical records.
Be a part of an OSHA inspection and speak with the inspector confidentially.
File a complaint with OSHA in case of any retaliation by their employer for acting as a “whistleblower”.

par.span: Employees also have certain responsibilities when it comes to workplace safety,
even though OSHA does not cite employees for violations. The employees have the following responsibilities:

li.span: Carefully read the OSHA Job Safety and Health poster.
Follow the workplace safety rules and use the required personal protective equipment (PPE).
In case of any conditions that pose a risk to the safety and well being of workers, employees must report to their supervisor or file a complaint with OSHA.
Responsibly exercise the rights given to them under the OSH Act.

par.span: The OSH Act resulted in the establishment of both The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH)
and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA).NIOSH was established to ensure safe and healthful working conditions by:

li.span: Gathering information;
Conducting scientific research;
Translating the knowledge gained to create relevant products and services; and
Providing training in the field of occupational safety and health.

par.span: NIOSH makes recommendations to OSHA, based on its research findings; regarding the creation or revision of OSHA standards.
Congress enacted a number of legislative acts in order to deal with the problems and threats posed by the industrial hazardous waste. These include:

li.span: Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA):The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) which was passed in 1976. The main goal of RCRA was to create a "cradle to grave" system for the recordkeeping of hazardous wastes. Under this the RCRA hazardous wastes must be tracked from the data-time they are generated until they are finally disposed of off on-site or off-site.

Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA):The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA), was passed by the congress in 1980. CERCLA regulates and enforces the clean-up and remediation of closed and abandoned hazardous waste sites.

SARA:The Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act (SARA) of 1986 amended CERCLA. This Act stressed the importance of permanent remedies and innovative treatment technologies for cleaning up of hazardous waste sites and increased the focus on human health problems caused by hazardous waste sites.

topics.name: Application of the HAZWOPER Standard to Chemical Spills

par.span: In order to get a better understanding of how the various sections of the HAZWOPER Standard apply to various groups;
let us apply this standard to chemical spills. There are two types of chemical spills:

li.span: Incidental release:These are simply cleaned-up.
Uncontrolled release:This type requires an emergency response effort and requires workers to be trained as responders.

par.span: The response effort is termed as “Emergency Response Phase”. The clean-up phase that follows an emergency response is called the “Post-Emergency Response Cleanup Operation”.
The next slide will illustrate the types of chemical spills and the application of the HAZWOPER Standard to these spills.

par.span: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) establishes workplace standards related to health and safety for various occupations.
To protect the health and safety of employees who deal directly with hazardous waste in their daily work
OSHA requires a 40-hour HAZWOPER training. This HAZWOPER certification must be renewed every year with an 8-hour refresher course.
The HAZWOPER training is required for anyone who is cleaning up hazardous waste sites,
working with hazardous waste at treatment, storage or disposal (TSD) sites, or responding to emergencies concerning the release of hazardous materials.
